dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREMELY WIDE SHOT: Fog. Nothing else in sight. Slowly, SMALL STEAM BOAT emerges: A LIGHTHOUSE TENDER. It chugs along, a tiny blip in a vast ocean. Black smoke puffs fro its crooked chimney. Its old engine sputters softly. Hold. The FOGHORN again, louder now. Closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The rotten, rusty prow carves through the waves The third-rate engine rumbles. Hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE: SHADOWS stand on the bow of the boat (back to CAMER They might be men, but they could just as easily be ghost THE FOGHORN BLASTS. It’s close enough to feel. A FLASH OF LIGHT breaks through the fog, revealing... The silhouette of a bleak stone island, no bigger than an acre: PILOT ROCK. A few ramshackle outbuildings cling to surface like barnacles. On the highest point of the islan stands a tall, crumbling LIGHTHOUSE TOWER. An ominous flo of SEAGULLS screech and caw around it. THE FOGHORN and LIGHT bellow and flash again. THE ISLAND itself seems to draw the boat and the men clos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dark in the fog, even with the flashing light above. A TRANSFER BOAT is beached on the shore. TWO RELIEF MATES doll out provisions to TWO MEN in dark uniforms and caps. hand-over is challenging.  The TWO UNIFORMED MEN come in and out of view, carrying supplies. One lags behind, carrying the heavier load. They walk past a small, dilapidated BOATHOUSE with no doo poorly mended DORY -- THE LIFE BOAT -- is tied up inside, sitting on the twisted runners of the launch that stretch into the lapping waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO OTHER MEN (late 60s, same uniforms) exit the one-stor CLAPBOARD SHACK that adjoins THE LIGHTHOUSE by a remarkab long breezeway. They are the departing LIGHTHOUSE KEEPERS “WICKIES,” as they refer to themselves. They lug gunny sa over their shoulders, and drag their rope-handled ditty b by their sides, keeping their heads down. Their bearded f are craggy and leaden. They reek of tobacco, must, and sa They shuffle toward their relief: THE MEN FROM THE TENDER carrying their supplies. The four almost exchange glances. But they don’t bother. THE FOGHORN bellows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new wickies stand utterly still, next to each other, their gazes fixed on the same distant spot. One man is YOUNG (early 30s). Tall, athletic -- but starv His deep set eyes are haunted, and his left eye is healin from a week-old shiner. His crooked expression is severe. There’s an eerie disquiet about him. He’s like a dog that been beaten and caged too many times. A small mustache sh his vanity. The other is OLD (Haggard 60? Spry 70?). He’s weathered, feral bearded, and hunched, with hands like vises. His la of visible lips suggests some missing teeth. He tremors a bit, but he’s lean and sturdy as a lead pipe. His high cheekbones smile even when he grimaces. His wild eyes shi like jewels. He’s an old Pan. A Satyr. Both of them seem like the kind of man you might find muttering to himself in the corner of an empty bar room w a distant look in his eye. They watch THE TENDER depart the island, ever-so-slowly disappearing -- swallowed up again by the fog.  THE FOGHORN bellows louder than ever, penetrating deep through the bodies of the two men. IT SHAKES THE YOUNG MA shocks him - but not the OLD one. He’s used to it. OLD puts the stump of an unlit clay PIPE in his mouth (up down). He lumbers out of frame, limping a bit, and happy finally be “home again.” YOUNG stays standing, staring out. A bit of fear strikes There’s no turning back now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG throws down his heavy supplies. They thud against the warped, mildewed floorboards. He walks through the kitchen and takes a look around... It’s run-down and spare: A coal range, a farmhouse sink w a water pump by the sole window, a small cupboard, a tabl and two chairs. The wind blows. It’s depressing. He keeps walking. He hears the sound of dribbling water (0.S.)...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entering the parlor, he sees: A reed splint rocker with a busted seat, a rattling potbelly stove, and a small, very dusty, government issue book chest. A CLOCK ticks monotonously. Then, YOUNG spots a fine DESK with a ship in a bottle on It’s rolled shut. He looks around, shifty eyed, to be sur one is watching him... Instinctively, he passes his hand along the top of the de to the LOCK. He jiggles it. Locked. Damn. Then, there is that persistent sound of dribbling water (O.S.)...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound grows louder as he climbs the narrow stairs, ev tread creaking along the way. The dribbling grows louder.  He enters the sleeping quarters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUD! YOUNG bumps his head on the low ceiling...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Son-of-a-- He shakes it off... The bunkroom is also dismal. Not much more than two saggi cast-iron single beds. OLD stands near his bed, PISSING INTO HIS CHAMBER POT. Pause. YOUNG absorbs the scene. YOUNG walks to the unoccupied bed and sits down. As soon he does, OLD FARTS about three feet away from YOUNG’S fac deliberate display of power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. OLD finishes relieving himself. He shakes his member. He buttons up, and kicks the pot under his bed. The piss nea sloshes out. Mercifully, it doesn’t. OLD limps away whistling (the song “Tis Brasswork”). He pauses briefly... FARTS again. He leaves frame, his UNEVEN GAIT disappearing: Walk-drag, walk-drag, walk-drag... YOUNG sits on his bed. Still. Simmering. He’s not pleased But he'll try to keep that to himself. He holds his head. The CLOCK from downstairs ticks... Just then, YOUNG feels something strange under him... He feels around... He discovers a hole in the mattress. Something is poking out... He digs his finger into the hole...  He removes some horsehair stuffing... He pulls out a small trinket, about six inches long... It MERMAID carved from ivory, with scrimshawed scales on her tail. A primitive but pretty effigy. Strange. YOUNG looks at it with a hungry curiosity... He rubs his thumb over her body... her breasts... He feels a bit guilty and puts her in his pocket. HOLD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The hulking steam-powered foghorn engine. A pis pumps, gears grind, a huge flywheel spins and spins.

dialogues.speaker: WITH FIRE.
dialogues.text: A SHOVEL FULL OF COAL enters frame and feeds the flames. Another shovel full. And another. THE FOG SIREN BLOWS EXCRUCIATINGLY LOUDLY. CLOSE, REVERSE: YOUNG shovels coal into the furnace, drip with sweat, wincing from the intense heat. He shovels again and again. THE FOG SIREN BLOWS: LOUD. CLOSE. PAINFUL. YOUNG BRACES HIMSELF, REELING FROM THE SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The contents of a kitchen cabinet are strewn about the fl OLD is inside the built-in cabinet up to his waist, butt If he had a tail, it’d wag. He’s looking for something. Something secret. YOUNG watches from afar in the staircase. OLD crawls out with a wooden crate. He grins with relief, pulling out a glass LIQUOR BOTTLE. He tremors a bit, it’s been too long

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dark. The two men sit in the cramped galley. A kerosene lamp flickers on the table between them, it is bent to one sid but still works fine. YOUNG looks at their meal, trying t hide his contempt: Lukewarm scrod and potatoes wait on battered mess plates. He rolls a cigarette on the table. coal-blackened hands stain the paper. OLD sets down two cups. Tin. Chipped china.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Should pale death with treble dread make the ocean caves our bed, God who hear'st the surges roll, deign to save the suppliant soul. He pours a strange, thick liquid into the cups. Homemade hooch? He holds his up for a toast.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To four weeks. YOUNG pauses. Damn, it looks good. He could use a drink. he hesitates as if he thinks he is being tested. He decides to stay focused on the cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: No, sir. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Bad luck to leave a toast unfinished, lad. YOUNG tucks his cigarette behind his ear.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Meanin’ no disrespect, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: A man what don’t drink, best have his reasons.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Ain't it--  7. YOUNG stops himself to rephrase, more respectfully. It’s easy for him to be well-mannered. He takes his time, so a not to fumble with the multisyllabic words. I'd -- I had understood it’s ‘gainst regulations, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Yessir. OLD won’t budge. His cup is still raised.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: From them’s manual.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Didn't picture you was a readin’ man.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Ain’t trying for trouble--

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Then y’do as I say. That’s in yer book, too. Long pause. YOUNG smiles. His expression seems to say: “This old guy piece of work.” YOUNG takes his cup very deliberately. He stands up. Pause. He walks to the farmhouse sink and pours out the booze. He pumps some water into his cup. He sits back down. He holds up his cup to toast. He’s proud. He won.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: To four weeks. OLD smiles -- a little too wide. They click cups. They drink...  8. Just as soon as they do: YOUNG RETCHES! A terrible taste. spits-up into his cup. A bit on the floor. OLD revels in the mishap.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Aye. The cistern needs a-lookin’ to. One of yer duties, lad. Or didn’t y’read yerself about it? Polishin’, swabbin’. Swabbin’ and polishin’. You’ll clean the brass and the clockwork, and you can tidy the quarters after. There’s well- more to be mended outside. YOUNG nods yes, his dry heaving subsiding.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: D’y’hear me, lad?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Yessir--

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (correcting him) “Aye, sir!”

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Aye, sir. OLD starts eating his supper. Happy. His habits are a bit uncouth.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: When the fog clears, you'll work through the dog watch--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Doggin’ it? Was ‘spectin’ I'd git up to the lantern.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: I tend the light.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: The rules is alternatin’ shifts-- OLD is startlingly stern. Unblinking. No tremors. A speck scrod hangs in his beard.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: It’s the mid watch that’s to dread, lad: night to morning. My watch. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some new junior man I’m fixed with-- Y’act like y’never been to sea a’fore.

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: YOUNG hesitates, he hasn’t been at sea before -- clearly. not worth the trouble getting into it now.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aye, sir. OLD looks at him with disgust.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: That uni’form don’t fit ye.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Well, sir, it’s the one them establishment fellers gave me--

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: I’m meanin’ y’ain’t fit fer the wearin’ of it. See to yer duties. The light’s mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME WIDE SHOT: THE LIGHTHOUSE flashes. THE FOGHORN blasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG shovels more coal into the furnace. ANGRY! He casts a mean glance to the BOOK that rests on a chair the hot, whirring machinery: “Instructions to Light-Keepe July, 1881.” He curses the manual:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Son-of-a-bitch. THE FOGHORN BLASTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CUE: Weird, haunting, ancient. THE CAMERA BOOMS UP THROUGH: The clinking and clanking ge of the light’s clockwork... A heavy lead weight on a chain slowly rises up through th center of the tower’s cast-iron spiral stairs... Wondrous patterns of swirling light move through the ironwork. The patterns shift rhythmically -- hypnotically. Otherworldly.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC CONTINUES.
dialogues.text: OLD sits in a sweat, mesmerized by the LIGHT. The machine whirs and clicks. THE HEAT from the huge THIRD-ORDER FRES LENS is immense. He is haloed in his pipe smoke. His jacket is off... Not cool enough. He opens his union suit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he’s bare-chested. His alcoholic's gut protrudes from wiry frame. His strong, sinewy arms shine with sweat. The a faded three-masted ship tattooed on his chest, and seve crooked stick-and-pokes elsewhere -- all glistening. He pours grog into his tin cup. He toasts the light. Drin His eyes are heavy. He’s not drunk yet. But he wants to be. He pours another drink. Toasts.  11.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: To ye, me beauty!

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC CONTINUES.
dialogues.text: YOUNG is staring up at the magical light. Eight beams -- rotating starburst. Weird light patterns dance across the rocks below. It truly is a wonder. He yearns for it. It’s primal. He’s outside the signal shed. It’s an odd looking buildin with a huge protruding trumpet, held up by rickety struts YOUNG tries to light his cigarette. The wind and dampness the foggy air makes it impossible. His match won’t light. THE FOGHORN BLASTS. YOUNG strikes the match again. The match is lit... the wi blows it out. Damn! He strikes the match again... THE FOGHORN BLASTS.

dialogues.speaker: MUSIC CONTINUES.
dialogues.text: YOUNG is finally smoking his cigarette. He slowly walks toward the shore... HE IS DRAWN TO THE LIGHT from the lighthouse reflecting o the water. He pauses, the waves lapping against the rocks. He starts walking into the tide... He walks further, he doesn't stop... HYPNOTIZED by the water... THE LIGHT...

dialogues.speaker: IS THAT A BALL OF LIGHT OUT IN THE SEA...
dialogues.text: Further...  12. Further... Seaweed, moss, and slime surround his knees. Further... Then, slowly, A HUGE LOG, forty feet long and still sheat in bark, floats toward him... Another log... Another! He looks ahead and THE SEA IS FULL OF LOGS: A RIVER LOG DRIVE. He wants to run, but he can’t... he keeps wading deeper into the ocean of logs... He is almost up to his neck in water... Suddenly, he sees THE BODY OF A MAN floating face down in the logs:

dialogues.speaker: THICK HOBNAILED SOLES.
dialogues.text: Nearby is some kind of tool floating: A WOODEN POLE WITH SINISTER IRON HOOK at the end of it (a peavey or “CANT HO for moving logs in a log drive). THE LOGS BEGIN TO JAM...

dialogues.speaker: THE BODY FLOATS TOWARD YOUNG
dialogues.text: YOUNG wants to scream. He is almost totally submerged now

dialogues.speaker: QUICK CUT TO
dialogues.text: IMAGE, WIDE: Underwater, A MERMAID swims gracefully -- MENACINGLY -- in the sea toward CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water drips on YOUNG'S FACE Drip. Drip. Drip. He opens his eyes, startled. OLD is disrobing in the mirror, carefully -- he’s drunk.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Shingles.  13. YOUNG looks up. Water gets into his eye. OLD waddles to his bed, his pants around his ankles.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tend to ‘em after the cistern. And the lamp, she needs oil. He flops down on the sagging mattress. Asleep instantly.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Aye, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG lugs a heavy BAG OF CHALK up the incline of the isl It’s hard work. The wind blows like hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG, cigarette in his mouth, opens the hatch of a porri brick water tank: It lets out a putrid stench that knocks YOUNG'S face back a few inches. He tosses away the cigarette and covers his mouth and nos with the handkerchief around his neck. He looks inside: It’s full of mold and frothy sludge. It’s what he’s been drinking. He pours in the chalk. It slowly sinks. YOUNG drops in the mixing stick and swirls the water arou It looks sort of beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG scrapes at old cedar shakes. Scrape. Scrape. Scrape. He balances precariously on a rickety rung ladder. The wi blows hard, nearly knocking him off. It’s monotonous work takes it seriously, but with a chip on his shoulder. He looks up to the lighthouse: Curtains drawn in the lamp room.  14. He rips out several rotted shingles. The roof boards belo are ravaged with rot, too. Yep, here’s that leaky hole. He leans in...

dialogues.speaker: HE CAN SEE THROUGH A HOLE IN THE ROOF
dialogues.text: OLD is asleep. But he’s moving... YOUNG leans in closer... OLD is softly HUMPING his sweaty mattress, just gently thrusting his hips. It’s subtle. A reflexive motion. YOUNG watches. Hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG opens a wooden door that almost falls off its hinge The shack is full. Barrels of dried fish, shelves of tool tapers, paper-wrapped parcels, wooden crates, casks, kegs rope...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG opens the door: COAL. Heaps of it. This door does fall off its hinges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He loads up a wheelbarrow overfull with coal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes the wheelbarrow down the rock. (Needless to say the wheel squeaks.) He keeps pushing. One wrong step could cause the whole pi to tumble off of the wheelbarrow and down the island....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes his way to the door with the wheelbarrow... A SEAGULL stands in front of the old door, guarding it.  15. YOUNG flaps his hand, trying to scare it. THE GULL SQUAWKS. It turns its head, revealing: A MISSING EYE. The empty socket is gruesome and twisted. A war woun YOUNG is motionless, staring at the strange deformity... SUDDENLY, THE GULL YEOWS, LUNGING at him, clicking its be Instinctively, YOUNG HURLS a lump of coal at it... He misses... THE GULL mews this time, looks with its single eye, and f away. YOUNG watches the bird’s path... It flies past the lighthouse... The OLD man is looking down at him from the TOWER CATWALK exterior observation deck), puffing his pipe. Watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The double-doors of the breezeway open, revealing: Oil dr at the bottom of the staircase. THE OIL ROOM. YOUNG looks up... That is one tall staircase. The chains of the light’s clockwork weights look sinister they dangle down the center of the iron spiral steps and their shadows creep across the stone wall. They clink and clank, echoing ominously... YOUNG looks at the OIL DRUMS hiding beneath the stairs. T are much larger and more imposing than the heavy chalk ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clunk. YOUNG lugs an immense OIL DRUM up the steps.  16. Clunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, YOUNG reaches the top of the stairs. The oil dru SLAMS down. His muscles tremor, sweat drips. He looks at the hatch to the LANTERN ROOM above... He is drawn to it... what’s in there? Slowly, he reaches toward the handle... He pushes... It’s closed. Stuck. Locked?

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don’t go in there! OLD startles YOUNG. Where did he come from? OLD emerges from the shadows: walk-drag, walk-drag, walk- drag.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Oil, sir. Says YOUNG, feeling somehow caught. He steps away from the drum, showing it to the old man, trying to hide an ounce of pride. He wipes the sweat from brow, panting. OLD limps around him, smoking his pipe. HE BLOWS SMOKE IN YOUNG’S FACE. YOUNG closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Tired?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: No, sir. Says YOUNG, still panting. OLD throws a small, empty, THREE-GALLON BRASS OIL CANISTE him. YOUNG CATCHES it awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use this next time. Save you a helluva lotta trouble.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: OLD continues to taunt him.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Catch yer breath, lad. Pause. I said catch your breath, lad! YOUNG grits his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then bring that drum back down the ladderwell where y’found it. ‘Less yer fixin’ to burn the whole light down. 17. OLD climbs the ladder to the LANTERN ROOM. YOUNG watches spite.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Aye, sir. OLD pulls out a KEY RING attached to his watch chain. A h dozen BRASS KEYS in varying sizes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Then see to the rest of yer duties. Yer behindhand already.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Aye, sir. YOUNG watches him unlock the door with the largest

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Yer too slow. You a dullard?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Fooled me. OLD slams the door and locks it from the inside. HOLD on YOUNG. KEY.  18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrod and potatoes again. YOUNG has his water. OLD pours himself a dram.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Should pale death with treble dread make the ocean caves our bed, God who hear'st the surges roll, deign to save the suppliant soul. They drink. YOUNG winces a little. OLD is satisfied and starts eating.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (between chewing) Still tastes o’the head? YOUNG won’t nod yes. They eat in silence. OLD looks up at YOUNG... YOUNG ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah, find some chirk in ye, lad. Now is the time for gab and chatter. Y’best be enjoying it. Come a fortnight and the brace of us’‘1l be wantin’ to be ever silent as the tomb. Even to clap eyes on each other... It’ll make y’hotter than hell!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I ain’t much fer talkin’.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Reckon yer the first?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: No, sir. I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Y’ain’t. Y’ain’t. Aye, the Chicopee, a fine-un, she were. Clean-built and trig-lookin’! None more fleet in ‘64 than she... We were on the breaks -- a mutiny it were. And why, ask ye? Why? What’s the terrible part of the sailor's life ask ye, lad? T’ain’t Cap’n, workin’ ‘em double-tide. Nay, no. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘Tis when the workin’ stops when yer twixt wind and water. Doldrums. Doldrums. Eviler than the Devil. Boredom makes men to villains... And the water goes quick, lad... vanished. And what’s the answer? What be the cure? The only med’cine is drink. Drink, lad! Keeps them sailors happy, keeps ‘em agreeable, keeps ‘em calm, keeps em--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Stupid. Pause. The two men stare at each other for a moment. OLD ERUPTS INTO A FIT OF LAUGHTER. He laughs so hard that runs through every conceivable sound. Is he drunk already YOUNG smiles in spite of himself, it’s hard not to. OLD pours another and toasts.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Curse me if there ain’t an old tar spirit somewheres in ye, lad. YOUNG starts to say something... but he stops himself. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Out with it, lad.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: What... Why’d yer last keeper leave?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Him? My second? YOUNG nods yes, eating.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A damn fine sea farin’ man, he were. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Aye, went mad, he did. First a strangeness. A quietude. Then wild fancies struck him. Ravin’ ‘bout sirens, merfolk, bad omens and the like. In the end, no more sense left in him than a hen’s tooth. He believed there were some enchantment in the light.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: He notioned St. Elmo did cast his very fire into it. Salvation, said he. YOUNG laughs.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Tall tales. He rolls a cigarette. OLD takes another drink. Slowly, his mood becomes somber.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: I seen ye sparrin’ with a gull. YOUNG licks the paper.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Best y’leave ‘em be. Bad luck to kill a sea bird. YOUNG laughs, dismissively.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: More tall tales? As YOUNG starts to put the cigarette to his lips... OLD G UP AND SLAPS HIM HARD IN THE FACE, out of nowhere! YOUNG stands in shock, knocking back his chair to the floor... He looks at OLD, stunned... YOUNG raises his fis defense... OLD IS ANGRY. DEAD SERIOUS.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Bad luck to kill a sea bird. Pause.  21. OLD breathes. He calms down a bit. He realizes how strang that was.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pay me no mind, lad. None. Fix us up some coffee. Long night ahead. Drop o’coffee‘ll do us good. OLD doesn’t need to say he’s drunk.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Aye, sir. YOUNG looks again at OLD: He’s shaken. Terrified. A shell himself. More frightening than his outburst of anger was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG lies in bed, smoking a cigarette. Reading the manua Can’t get comfortable. Restless. He holds the CARVED MERM in his hand, rubbing it reflexively in all the wrong plac The CLOCK ticks monotonously. Hold. OUT OF FOCUS IN THE BACK GROUND: A SEAGULL lands on the window. Pause. THE GULL starts tapping on the window. Tap. Tap. YOUNG hears it. Tap. Just as he turns to face it... THE SEAGULL has flown away YOUNG feels uneasy. He sits up. Back to his bed: the MERMAID CARVING is nestled in his sheets. Waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG'S head moves up and down, shaking slightly. He is hiding in the shadows of the shed. The sound of rustling cloth and a clinking belt buckle are heard. CAMERA BOOMS DOWN...  22. He’s masturbating. CAMERA DOLLIES INTO: YOUNG’S head and into ... BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG emerges from the darkness of the shed, smoking. He closes the door behind him and leans against it. He sighs Soothed. Calm. The LIGHTHOUSE LIGHT illuminates YOUNG in waves of hot wh panels, otherwise, the soft glow of his cigarette indicat his location in the dark. Suddenly, he notices something odd, a DARK SPOT in the ce of the light. The panels of light streaking across him ha MAN'S SILHOUETTE within them. YOUNG looks up to the tower YOUNG'S POV: Is that OLD... hugging the lens? YOUNG is startled, confused. He looks again. YOUNG'S POV: Somehow, OLD is now on the CATWALK. Surveyin He pulls suspenders over his shoulders, as if getting dre after a night with a woman. A lantern in his other hand h him look below.... YOUNG skulks beneath the eaves of the roof, wary of the m above. He puts out his glowing cigarette... Hiding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREMELY WIDE SHOT: YOUNG pushes the wheelbarrow through storm, an oilcloth tarp over the coal. (Time has passed, shiner has healed.) He struggles through the mud... Hold.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: You've been neglecting yer duties, lad!  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG is still, holding a rag against the brass he’s polishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD is fuming.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Don’t deny it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD stands in the galley, pointing at the floor in horror looks like it always does. How could it look any differen

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: What d’y’call this?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I mopped and swept. Twice over, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Ye lyin’ dog.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I swept ‘em--

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: ‘Tis begrimed and bedabbled.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Unwiped, unwarshed, and distained.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: (under his breath) You git some kinda peart outta molestin’ me?  That sets 24.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Come now?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I already says--

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: How dare y’contree’dict me, y’dog-- YOUNG off:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Now look here, I ain't never intended to be no housewife nor slave in takin’ this job. It ain’t right! These lodgings is more ramshackle than any shanty boy’s camp I ever seen. The queen of England’s own fancy housekeeper couldn’t do no better than what I done, ‘cause I tell you, I scrubbed this here place twice over, sir and-

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: And I say y’did nothin’ o’the sort. I say, y’swab it again, and y’swab it proper-like this time, and then you'll be swabbin’ it ten times more after that. And if I tells ye to pull up and apart every floorboard and clapboard of this here house and scour ‘em down with yer bare, bleedin’ knuckles, you'll do it. If I tells ye to yank out every single nail from every moulderin’ nail-hole and suck off every spec of rust till all them nails sparkle like a sperm whale’s pecker, and then carpenter the whole light station back together from scrap -- and then -- do it all over again -- you'll do it! And by God and by Golly, you'll do it smilin’ lad, cause you'll like it, too. And you'll like it ‘cause I says you will! Contree’dict me again I dock yer wages. Y'hear me, lad?  25. Long, painful pause.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Aye, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Now swab, dog. Swab! YOUNG does as he’s told - he grabs the mop and pail, fina resigned to his fate on this light station. OLD smiles.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now that’s a good lad. That’s what I like to see. YOUNG starts to mop. OLD sings mockingly:

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (singing) Oh what be the bane of a lightkeeper's life? What cause him to worry, to struggle and strife, What make him use cuss words, and beat at his wife? ‘Tis Brasswork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD watches YOUNG polishing the brasswork.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (singing) What make him look ghastly, consumptive and thin? What rob him of health, of his vigor and vim? And cause him despair and drives him to sin.' ‘Tis Brasswork. YOUNG keeps polishing... harder... faster... harder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG pushes the wheelbarrow through the storm (now in th other direction). It’s more difficult than before...  26.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (singing) The oil containers I polish until, My poor back is broken, aching; and still... He’s struggling... The wheelbarrow falls... Coal scatters all over the place. YOUNG stands still. He wants to scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG and OLD eat their scrod and potatoes in silence. RAIN AND WINDS BLAIR JUST OUTSIDE THEIR FLIMSY WALLS. Tension. Hold. Thunder claps. BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: OLD is looking down from CATWALK of the tower, smokes his pipe. The sun shines behind him. CAMERA BOOMS DOWN TO: YOUNG, sitting on a KITCHEN CHAIR h up by ropes, attached to a jerky BLOCK AND TACKLE. One of wheels is coming off the pulley. YOUNG is whitewashing the tower, some 50 feet above the ground. A bucket of whitewash dangles on another rope.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Keep ‘em still, lad. YOUNG can’t. As usual, the wind blows wildly.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Aye, sir. His "paintbrush," a stick with a horsehair brush at the e shakes in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Whitewash must be even, lad. Bright! Shinin’! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like a silver whorehouse token. Give ‘em sailors a proper daymark. OLD lets the rope slip a bit. It truly scares YOUNG. Whitewash drips onto YOUNG’S face and clothes. He yells:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: They're not going to see it ina Goddamn storm! OLD laughs.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: They will after! And'1ll be glad to see it! Keep your temper now, lad. ‘Tis fine work. Yer makin’ high marks in me logbook. Them’s gospel! “Logbook?” thinks YOUNG. He stares at Old... for too long

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll drop y’down a few feet. OLD lowers him some more; YOUNG slips quickly. Suddenly.. The pulley whirls too fast... YOUNG and the moving block shift quickly and SLAM to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Easy.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Never been in better hands. Another shift: HARD. Is OLD struggling? He anchors his good leg to the catwalk SHIFT! Further than the last one. THE WHITEWASH SPLASHES.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Easy! YOUNG thrashes in the wind...

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Quit yer flailing, lad.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I ain’t!

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Y'are!  28.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep still!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I am-- THE PULLEY’S BUSTED WHEEL FLIES OFF... the rope springs backward... YOUNG, the chair, and the block and tackle plunge to the ground! BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG comes to... He's covered in whitewash. How long was he out? He looks around... THE KITCHEN CHAIR shattered -- no more than kindling... OLD is nowhere to b seen... But THE SEAGULL with the missing eye is perched on his le It pecks him, scavenging the fresh meat.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Shoo. It pecks again. TAP. TAP. TAP. On his leg. The GULL blurt out a hostile kek

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You! Git! It persists, pecking with its sharp beak. YOUNG is afraid of the bird. Afraid to harm it... TAP. TAP. TAP. Damn! It hurts!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG KICKS IT HARD
dialogues.text: THE GULL flies away, mocking him with mews and yeows  29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD peers through tiny, delicate spectacles worn at a can The left temple tip is too high, and not looped round his ear. He is finishing writing an entry in his LOG BOOK. He writ the “period” with gusto. Pen down. Book closed. Glasses off. He rolls his desk top shut with a slam, and locks it with littlest KEY on his key chain. CAMERA pushes into the lock. REVERSE: YOUNG IS HIDING IN THE SHADOWS of the vestibule. WATCHING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD sits on the same chair he’s been sitting in for the p weeks. YOUNG sits on an upturned NAIL KEG. YOUNG turns HARDTACK in his hand. He’s debating eating it KNOCKS it against the table. The biscuit clangs like meta Nope. YOUNG pours OLD a drink instead. Passes it to him.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Thankee, lad.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Winslow.
YOUNG musters a little courage.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Ephraim Winslow. These last two weeks, I'd... well, I’d like it, sir, if you’d call me by my name.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Listen to ye, giving orders, lad.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Winslow.  30.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Alright, alright... suits me just as fine, Ephraim Winslow. So, what brung such a one as you to this damnéd rock?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Such as what?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Pretty as a picture.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: OLD laughs heartily.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Only joshing, lad, only josh--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Winslow.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Winslow -- What brings you to this rock, Ephraim Winslow? What were yer work afore?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Timber.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Timber...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Big timber. Up north. Canada ways.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Hudson Bay outfit?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: The same.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: True what they say? “Forest far as the eye can see.”

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Yessir. Spruce, tamarack... white pine. “Bush,” them folk up there call it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Had enough of trees, that it, then?  31.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Can’t say I blame ye. I hearn tell about that life. Hard goin’. Workin’ one man harder than two hosses, they say. No thankee. The sea, she’s the only situation wantin’ fer me.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Miss it?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Miss it? I ain’t never know’d anything but it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Sailing.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Ah... Aye. Aye. OLD sees the sea life clearly in his eyes. The stories he must have.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ain’t nothing what can touch it. He snaps himself out of it: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But can’t be draggin’ me old stump about... (Referring to his limp) Nay... not worth the trouble... now I’m a wickie and a wickie I is. I’m damn-well wedded to this here light, and she’s been a finer, truer, quieter wife than any a live- blooded woman.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Ever married?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Thirteen Christmases at sea... little ‘uns at home. She never forgave it. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘Tis fer the better. Pause. It’s clear that OLD has regrets. But rather than dwell on painful past, he changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Since we're getting too friendly, Ephraim Winslow, tell me, what’s a timber man want with being a wickie? Not enough quiet for ye up north? Sawdust itching yer nethers? Foreman found ye too high-tempered for carrying an axe? That last comment rubs YOUNG the wrong way, but he tries to give in to the feeling.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Like you says, just had enough of trees, I guess. OLD looks him over suspiciously as he lights his pipe. YOUNG focuses on his cigarette. Lights. Draws.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Since I left Dad, well... I done every kind of work can pay a man. Some I ain’t near proud of.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Drifter, eh?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: No sir! Just can’t find a post I can take a real shine to, so I keep movin’ along. And I ain’t the kind to look back at what’s behind him, see.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: On the run? YOUNG gets defensive. Did he say too much?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: No sir -- now look here, now -- I mean, nothin’ wrong with a man startin’ fresh, startin’ new, lookin’ to earn a living--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: ...like any man, tryin’ to settle down quiet-like with some earnings... I read a man could earn six hundred and thirty -- I read one thousand dollars a year if he’s willing to tend a light far off shore... the further away, the more he earns. I read that, and hell, I says, yessir. Work. Save my earnings. Soon enough, I’1ll raise my own roof, somewheres up country, with no one to tell me “what for”... That’s all. YOUNG smiles. He thinks he is doing a pretty good job covering up his fear that OLD may sense more than he lets The cigarette helps.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Same ol’ borin’ story, eh?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: You asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD sits in his rocker, knitting, smoking his pipe. YOUNG sits on the floor by the open stove, warming his ha He lights his cigarette with a splinter of kindling and closes the door. He takes a drag.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Say, why’s it bad luck to kill a gull? OLD puffs his pipe gravely.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: In ‘em’s the souls o’ sailors what met their maker. YOUNG tries not to scoff again. OLD senses it.  34.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You a prayin’ man, Winslow?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Not as often as I might. But I’m God fearin’ -- if that’s what yer askin’. YOUNG tries to take another drag of his cigarette. He can It’s gone out... but he just lit it...

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Russian Tar once told me: yer cigarette cinder goes out, there be someone somewhere’s a-thinkin’ bad thoughts of ye. YOUNG looks at OLD. OLD stops rocking.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They be a-cursing yer name. YOUNG re-lights the cigarette and takes a drag, not knowi what to make of that.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A toast to Ephraim Winslow, the God fearin’ man. Let ‘im settle down with none to tell ‘em “what for,” that his cinders always stay burnin’, and let fear never abandon ‘im. OLD toasts and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Amen. YOUNG feels uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - YOUNG sweeps the galley. - OLD ascends the tower stairs. He pauses, out of breath. - YOUNG is inside the fog trumpet, cleaning it. - OLD swiftly rolls his DESK closed and LOCKS IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - YOUNG winds the clockwork mechanism.  35. - YOUNG cleans the clockwork. Leaning in a strange positi his TOBACCO POUCH falls to the ground. - OLD goes into the LANTERN ROOM and LOCKS IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG is tossing and turning in bed. Restless. Hot. Sweat The sound of the waves crashing on shore is relentless. The CLOCK ticks monotonously. He tries to find a cool spot on the bed. He turns his pillow over... kicks off the linens like an angry toddler... He’s only in his underwear. The MERMAID carving is in bed his side. (Pinned on the wall behind him are clippings of desired objects from a Sears and Roebuck catalogue, a Tenderloin music hall program, and a few pornographic playing cards. Kicking off the linens doesn’t help. He sits up. He puts hand behind his ear... no cigarette. He goes to his shirt pocket hanging on the foot of the be rail... The TOBACCO POUCH isn’t there.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CUE: The eerie “light” music. YOUNG sees the POUCH resting on top of the spinning clockwork. He grabs it and quickly starts to head down stairs, but... Something stops him. A feeling. A question. The clockwork spins, the light hums on its brass track, t sea and wind sing their lilting song.  36. He looks up at the LIGHT swirling magically, undulating through the cast-iron lens deck. It is beautiful. Hypnoti THE LIGHT DRAWS HIM IN... But there’s something else... another noise... Whispering. Above. In the LANTERN ROOM. YOUNG tries to look through the iron grates of the lens d the bright LIGHT of the lamp makes it hard to see... he n to get closer... He grabs a chair from the shadows and stands on it. He listens. The whispering is more audible, though hard to define. He listens, trying to block out the white noise of the light It’s OLD all right, but YOUNG can only hear bits of whisp

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (whispered) The light... seed... There’s another noise, now that his ear is more focused. It's a sticky, sweaty, slapping of flesh. Constant... It’s familiar... He puts his face closer to the iron and through glimpses the light and shadow above, he sees:

dialogues.speaker: DOWN.
dialogues.text: Is he...? JUST THEN, WHITE, VISCOUS FLUID DRIPS FROM THE GRATES... YOUNG QUICKLY AVOIDS IT IN DISGUST. HE LOOKS UP AGAIN... A HUGE, SLIMY, TRANSLUCENT SQUID’'S TENTACLE SLITHERS ACR THE IRONWORK... ...IT DISAPPEARS INTO THE DARKNESS.  37.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (louder) Veritas... YOUNG’s eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG pumps water into a cup in the sink. He drinks. Pumps again. Drinks. Goes to pump again, but something stops him.. At the bottom of the cup is a dark film. He sweeps it up with a finger and looks: strange. Then, TAP, TAP, TAP on the window. He doesn’t seem to hea YOUNG pumps the water once again... it makes a rusty gurg sound... the water is more and more tainted, almost black Just then, he hears THE PLAINTIVE CRY OF A GULL, outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG exits the back door of the quarters. He looks out t the cistern. The CRY continues. He walks slowly toward the cistern. THE CISTERN'S HATCH IS OPEN. The CRY gets louder as he approaches. He looks in: DEAD GULLS float in the bloody cistern. ONE SEAGULL is tr to escape -- pathetically, desperately -- crying. Its win broken. JUST THEN, A LOUD FLUTTER OF WINGS IS HEARD ABOVE... and sound of a gull landing. YOUNG LOOKS UP...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG is frozen. Then, THE GULL swoops his beak into the cistern... he gra the gull in his beak, and begins to eat it. YOUNG tries to intervene... ONE-EYE ATTACKS YOUNG’S FACE! YOUNG TEARS IT AWAY IN WILD RAGE...

dialogues.speaker: THE ONE-EYED GULL IS DEAD.
dialogues.text: YOUNG breathes heavily. Guilty. Hold. The wind blows softly. He makes himself a cigarette, shaking. He looks sheepishl to the tower to see if OLD is watching. CAMERA BOOMS UP THE LIGHTHOUSE TOWER, past the catwalk, p the lamp, past the conical roof to... THE WEATHERVANE: THE ARROW POINTS WEST... Suddenly, the wind gusts... THE ARROW starts to jiggle a bit... The wind picks up... THE ARROW spins around, and around, around... It settles. Jiggling slightly in the wind, THE ARROW POIN HARD: EAST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG stands in the open doorway of the bunkroom, wiping face with a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Cistern was open, sir and...  39. He sees OLD sobbing into his pillow and blankets. He’s as -- isn’t he? It's a strangely vulnerable sight. YOUNG doesn’t know what to do. Hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG'S face is reflected in the shining brasswork. His expression is still affected by the previous two scenes. spits on the brass and keeps polishing. OLD watches YOUNG work, writing in his logbook.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Wind’s changed.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Good riddance.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Don’t be so darn foolish. It’s the calm afore the storm, Winslow. She were a gentle westerly wind yer cursin’. Only feels roughly ‘cause you don’t know nothin’ bout nothin’ and there ain’t no trees on this here rock like your Hudson Bay bush. Nor’Easterly wind’1l come soon a-blowin’ like Gabriel's horn. Best board up them signal house winders.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Aye, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: ‘Twill keep steady afore the tender comes in the morn, I ‘spect... but there’s dirty weather knockin’ about. YOUNG won't look OLD in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Somethin’ stirring in ye? Yer gettin’ off this island tomorry Winslow, don’t start grudgen me now.  40.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Keeping secrets, are ye?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: No, sir. Pause. I could use a hand with them boards, is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG boards up the windows. OLD helps.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now then, I’ve a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG stands precariously on a rock, pulling a ROPE that leads out into the water. OLD watches him.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Pull, pull, me good lad. Pull, Winslow! YOUNG pulls a wooden LOBSTER POT out of the water. YOUNG SMILES. So does OLD.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at ‘em! Better than fin fishin’!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mutilated LOBSTER SHELLS are piled up on the plates. By t look on YOUNG & OLD’S faces, it was a satisfying meal. OLD pours two cups of his grog. Passes one to YOUNG.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: ‘Tis no crime to take a snort now. A clear night. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And bein’ our last afore relief, I never know’d an inspector what wouldn't turn a blind eye, and I won’t take “no” for an answer. YOUNG gives in. He takes the cup.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Should pale death and treble dread make the... uh... Pause. He can’t remember the rest.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah hell -- to relief! They clink.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: And how! They drink. YOUNG remembers how much he’s been missing the drink.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Damn! Like comin’ home. OLD pours another round. They drink. OLD pours another round. They drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG AND OLD are singing and pounding on the table.

dialogues.speaker: OLD AND YOUNG
dialogues.text: (singing) Hurrah, we're homeward bound, Hurrah, we're homeward bound!

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (singing) When we're arrived on Bedford docks Them bloomers all comin’round in flocks Them pretty girls, we hear 'em say "Here comes Jack with his nine- month pay"  42.

dialogues.speaker: OLD AND YOUNG
dialogues.text: (singing) Hurrah, we're homeward bound, Hurrah, we're homeward bound!

dialogues.speaker: -PARLOR. LATER
dialogues.text: They keep drinking. OLD smokes a cigarette. YOUNG smokes OLD’S pipe.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: ...and a pretty lass, she were, takin’ off her bonnet... but as I says, I'd broke me leg, and banged myself all up. It was to a nuns' hospital... All of them nuns were Catholics, I tell ye... They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aye, but I never went to Salem since without hoping that I should see her, for beddin’ down wer’nt the same since. I don't know, but if I was a-goin’ to begin me life over again... well, womenfolk are apt to be dreadful ashamed of it, anyhow.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: You feel shame when you lie with a woman?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: I ain’t ‘shamed of nothing. Pause. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I’1l say it... I might even miss ye, Ephraim Winslow, yer fastly a true blue wickie in the making, you is. Thought one night you was bound to split me skull in twain, but yer a good-un. Why you'll be workin’ the lamp in no time -

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Why haven't I?  43. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: The light?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: I'm the keeper of this station, lad.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The... I ain’t... Some other station y’can tend the light.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: The manual says--

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: My log is the only book on this rock--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, I’m a wickie, you ‘Tis Gospel! says, but I ain’t trimmed one wick once--

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm the keeper of the light, lad, I never let no man touch her--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ain’t -- the book says we Don’t concern yerself with alternate-- the beacon! Mine, lad! OLD pours himself another drink. YOUNG laughs. The tension goes away.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Have it yer way... uh... Say, I never... I don’t know yer name.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Wake.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Yer Christian name?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG looks odd, troubled.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Thomas?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Thomas Wake, aye. YOUNG seems a little disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Call me Tom. OLD pours them another round.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: To my friend Tom, and to gittin’ off this goddamned rock! They drink, spilling a bit of the liquor down their chins YOUNG snaps out of whatever seemed to be bothering him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG stumbles around, undressing as he makes his way to bed. He leaves clothes here and there. He struggles to get his boots off. He can’t. Too drunk. He sits and breathes. He tries again. He gets one off. He tries the other... no use... He pulls harder, it comes loose, but the force is so great, YOUNG hits his head on lamp, mounted on the wall... He and the lamp crash to the floor. He passes out with hi pants around his ankles. His hair absorbs the kerosene of broken lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG wakes up. He is so hung over. He wants to die. He needs water... The pitcher... the basin... both empty. He knocked them o  45. the night before. When did that happen? He looks down the staircase: OLD is asleep, sprawled out the steps. YOUNG goes to his chamber pot: it’s full of piss and shit He goes to Old's: piss and shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG wears his oilskins, smokes a cigarette, and carries full piss pots. THE WIND FIGHTS HIM. So does the hangover

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG stands over the cliffside. He tosses the contents of the CHAMBER POTS off the cliffs IT ALL SPLASHES BACK IN HIS FACE.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Fuck! He drops the chamber pots... they tumble to the rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG hauls coal, his face covered in shit. It rains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG stokes the fire. The siren is up and running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG stumbles around the slippery rocks, pushing an empt wheelbarrow. Rain pissing on him. The hangover beating do upon his head. THE FOGHORN blasts relentlessly.  46. As he rounds a corner, he sees something WHITE in the bla rocks of the shore... He walks a few more paces... It is a BODY, lying still. Is it a dead sailor? He gasps... He drops the wheelbarrow and runs toward it! THE FOGHORN blasts. As he gets closer, it appears to be a WOMAN... A NUDE WOM washed up on the rocks. White legs and arms splayed out. He calls for Old, but he can’t hear him. He runs closer. THE FOGHORN blasts again. THE WOMAN appears to be DEAD, entangled in seaweed. YOUNG has to save her if he can. YOUNG goes to his knees... Wipes seaweed away from her face... SHE IS BEAUTIFUL. The most beautiful woman he has ever se The blood rushes to his head. His heart throbs. He looks over. He wants to touch her. He hesitates... but he does. He checks her pulse... Puts his head to her chest: Dead. Slowly, he touches her cheek, then her mouth... He moves his hand down her body, in the horror and grief her death, but also fascinated by her beauty, her perfect feminine shape... He makes his way past her breasts, to h ribs... Her ribs seem to have wounds -- deep slices. They aren’t bloody. They look almost like... GILLS. He moves his hand past her waist, toward her genitals, th he sees: SHE HAS A FISH’S TAIL! SHE IS A MERMAID!! He is frozen in terror. Then he looks back at her face... She opens her eyes and smiles at him.  47. She raises her arms, wanting his embrace... YOUNG opens his mouth to scream in horror... THE FOGHORN blasts! YOUNG runs away, fast as he can, flailing, stumbling over himself. He has almost no control over his body as he hur himself across the island, his screams drowned out by the FOGHORN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG is out of breath from screaming. Wild eyed.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: What’r y’splittin’ yer lungs fer?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Y’smell o’ shit. Best swab this mess afore the tender comes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Y¥'do as yer told, lad! The quarters are dire.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Aye, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GALLEY IS CLEAN. Well, as clean as it can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BUNKROOM is orderly. Mattresses rolled up. Everything in place. The CLOCK ticks monotonously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD and YOUNG are in their topcoats, their gunny sacks ov their shoulders, their ditty boxes by their sides. They l out to sea, waiting for the tender.  48. It rains. The wind blows. Hold. The rain begins to pour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG AND OLD sit at the table perfectly still. Drenched. A lit cigarette hangs on YOUNG’S bottom lip. The storm outside is something biblical. Very, very long pause.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: They didn’t come. Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: Huge waves crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: Enormous waves crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain pours. A deluge. OLD is in his oilskins. He stands like a magician in fron the BOATHOUSE, facing the waves. He holds his right hand the sea with two fingers extended. He holds his bottle in other hand. He counts the waves as they crash onto the shore.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: -..Four ...Five ...Six The waves are growing higher!

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...Seven ...Eight ...Go down! He makes the sign of the cross (like a Catholic) on the n wave, and DOUSES THE SEA with liquor from his bottle.

dialogues.speaker: THE WAVE FLOUNDERS AND DIES...
dialogues.text: OLD smiles at himself. I’ve still got it, he thinks. He t a swig from his bottle... Did he really make the wave descend? Or is it a coinciden Regardless, the wind comes back with a vengeance ... Behind him, the DORY that’s tied up wracks in the wind, beating against the sides of the boat house. The foghorn calls. The light flashes.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (singing “Blood Red Roses”) ‘Tis frost and snow and winter storm. (beat) Go down ye blood red roses, go down! (beat) And there’s many a ship lost round Cape Horn. (beat) Go down ye blood red roses, go down! (beat) Oh, ye pinks and posies... EIGHT... Go down! NINE! He makes the sign of the cross. Douses the sea. He stops singing and shouts:

dialogues.speaker: GIFT, QUENCH THY SPLEEN, AND ABATE
dialogues.text: He tosses some more liquor into the sea, and takes anothe swig himself.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (singing) Well, the captain he's o’er come with fear. Go down --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: THE BAROMETER. The needle is falling. It falls “RAIN” to “STORM.” YOUNG has his shirt off, shoveling coal. Sweaty. He has bits rags shoved in his ears, trying to muffle the sound. THE FOGHORN blasts. YOUNG catches his breath. He has one of OLD’S LIQUOR BOTT on his chair. He uncorks the bottle of liquor. Smells it. He thinks hard about drinking it. No. He corks it. He lights a cigarette instead. YOUNG turns... OLD is in the doorway soaking wet, and crazed. YOUNG wants to ask what happened, but decides it’s better to. YOUNG somehow feels too exposed without his shirt on.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (yelling over the noise) THE DAMP’S GOT TO THE PROVISIONS.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: (yelling over the noise)

dialogues.speaker: WHAT
dialogues.text: YOUNG pulls the scraps of fabric from his ears.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (yelling over the noise) THE DAMP’S GOT TO THE PROVISIONS!  51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TWO walk through the storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD is shutting the door. YOUNG is shaking off the rain.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: The damp’s got to the foodstuffs. The salt cod is out.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Out?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Blasted. Gone to rot.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Praised be.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Now will y’hear me?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Hear what?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: That we best be rationing.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Rationing?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Insubordinate again--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: It’s only been one day.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: The Devil’s tail! YOUNG can’t figure out OLD’S train of thought.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Look, maybe the tender, maybe she did come. We missed her, is all. I can take the dory out--

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Weeks, Winslow.  52.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: What d’ye mean, what?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Weeks? YOUNG is beginning to feel confused, afraid.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Weeks, aye. Weeks.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: We slept in. Dead drunk.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: It’s been weeks ago since we missed her, Winslow. And I’ve been askin’ ye to ration fer weeks now, too, and you've kept barking at me like a mad dog, sayin’ you can “take the dory out”--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Now look--

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Don’t be losing yer head now.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: This ain’t funny.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: No, it ain’t. And I ain’t wantin’ to be stranded here with some damned lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Stranded?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: That’s what I said.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I thought you said relief was comin’.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: If we can wait out this storm.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: The tender is comin’.  53. He says, trying to convince himself.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: In ‘75 ‘Ol Striker were marooned here for seven long months, he was. The storm died on the mainland but here, waters were too rageful neither to launch nor land.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Yer just tryin’ to scare me. YOUNG is worried he is losing his mind. Or is it OLD who’ losing it?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Look at ye. Pretendin’. But ye well- know yer lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storm continues. OLD holds two SHOVELS. He throws the shorter one at YOUNG.

dialogues.speaker: DIG.
dialogues.text: OLD starts digging like a madman in the wind and rain.

dialogues.speaker: DIG, SAYS I
dialogues.text: YOUNG joins, afraid of what they might be digging up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEY have dug a deep, muddy hole. About the size of a GRA

dialogues.speaker: HERE SHE LIES.
dialogues.text: OLD unearths... A WOODEN CRATE. He gives it to YOUNG.

dialogues.speaker: -MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: They open it...  54. INSIDE ARE TEN FULL BOTTLES OF BOOZE.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: (to himself, ironic) Rations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TWO DRINK while they ration out supplies. OLD is marshalling YOUNG. They are pretty drunk already. YOUNG EYES A LEDGER written in the LOGBOOK, marked with pounds of coal, number of tins, gallons of oil, etc. OUTSIDE, THE RAIN HAMMERS DOWN. WIND HOWLS.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: ... their gums grew swollen, the color of bone, then to rot. Tarry blood oozed, teeth droppin’ to deck with none to hold on to. OLD proudly shows off his missing front teeth. Their legs withered and turned gangree’nous, every shade of the peacock’s tail. The worst of us couldn't fend ‘gainst the ship rats what gnawed at the soles of our feet. “Land ho!” hears I, but only grass and trees on that island. So we drunk upon the sap, and et upon the grass. ‘Twas providence saved us from turnin’ to each other’s flesh, like bare-naked savages. And ‘twas that scurvy what left me locked ever since. He knocks on his leg again. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Thought you said you broke it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Eh?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Yer leg. Catholic nuns, and such like.  55.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: .--No, y’must’a misheard. YOUNG looks at OLD suspiciously. OLD reciprocates. CAMERA REVEALS: YOUNG is secretly pocketing a DINNER KNIF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG is on the floor, pouring himself another. TWO EMPTY BOTTLES are by him. He takes another swig.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: No, no, no. No! And I says git off me, I says. OLD sits on Young’s bed, staring out the window, fixated the horrible STORM which is tearing the outbuildings apar He holds A MOSTLY EMPTY BOTTLE.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Fallin’. Fallin’.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: But they never listened... they’d never... if I had the chance, they’d never -- none of them Goddamned lily-livered Canadian bastards. Lack-gall cowards. Those bastard didn’t fight no revolution - - never -- and look at em! Cowards and he-women all of ‘em. Goddamn ‘em! OLD keeps staring out the window.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: The eaves be fallin’ fast.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Never! Any day, breaking my back, working a man harder than two horses, but Winslow, Winslow... I told that dumb bastard...

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Yep. Them eaves is gonners.  OLD turns. Pause. 56.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Give me yer cant hook, I says to him, but foreman Winslow that goddamned Canady son-of-a-bitch fool bastard... always callin’ me a dog. A filthy dog.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Winslow?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Yeah, that bastard. “I’1ll show you who’s a dog.”

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Winslow?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: What of him?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Who, Winslow? The eaves be fallin’--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: He’s always raggin’ on me, like you. Damn fool nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Raggin'?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: How'd you find yourself off that grass island anyhow?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Raggin’? Who’s raggin’? What island? That’s the trouble with ye, Winslow.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s the trouble with Winslow.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: That’s the trouble with ye! YOUNG takes a swig and looks OLD in the eye.  Pause. 57.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: The trouble with you is eatin’ grass without no teeth.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Come now?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Yer sea maties’ teeth was fallen out--

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: What’re ye getting at, Winslow?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Just... just, it seems powerful hard to eat grass without no teeth. Goats and sheeps and cows. Well now, they all got teeth, don’t they?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Y’know how y’eat grass without haven’ yer teeth?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Oblige me.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Ye rip it out and ye swallow it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: You rip it out and you swallow it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Ye rip it out and--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I don’t know ‘bout that.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Y'don’t?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: What?  Pause. What? What? What? What? What? What?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (quickly, on his heels) What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: (faster) What?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (even faster) What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: (as fast as possible) What?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (faster than that) What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (CONT'D) (CONT'D) (CONT'D) (CONT'D) (CONT'D) (CONT'D)
Pause. 59.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: That’s what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: That’s the trouble with you.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: That’s the trouble with ye!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: With you!!

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: With YE!!!

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: (Suddenly) I want a steak! I want a goddamned

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Shut it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: A steak! A steak! A rare, bloody steak. If I had a steak, I could, oh boy, I could fuck it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: You don’t like my cookin’?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Don’t be such an old bitch.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: You’re drunk, you don’t know what yer talkin’--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: How could I possibly like the horseshit you fix us for supper?  60. YOUNG (CONT’D) OLD Them tin kitchen shanty cooks Yer drunk, or ye wouldn’t b gave us fried donuts three saying that! Yer drunk! Yer times a day and country ham drunk! Yer drunk! bigger than yer fist.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I’m drunk? I’m drunk?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Ye heard me.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: You’ve been drunk since...

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Damn ye.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Drunk since I first laid eyes on you.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Yer fond of me lobster, ain’t ye?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Yer drunker than a Virginy fence.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: I seen it, yer fond of me lobster.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Say it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Say it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: OLD is furious.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Damn ye!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I don’t have to say nothin--  61.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Let Neptune strike ye dead, Winslow! OLD becomes dreadfully serious. YOUNG is afraid. Silent. OLD speaks more powerfully and passionately than any Tamburlaine or Lear. He calls out to the gods of the sea Man possessed:

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hark, Triton, Hark! Bellow, and bid our father, the sea king, rise up from the depths, full- foul in his fury, black waves teeming with salt-foam, to smother this young mouth with pungent slime... (to Young) «+. to choke ye, engorging yer organs till ye turn blue and bloated with bilge and brine and can scream no more... only when, he, crowned in cockle shells with slithering tentacled tail and steaming beard, takes up his fell, be-finnéd arm -- his coral-tined trident screeches banshee-like in the tempest and runs you through the gullet, bursting ye, a bulging bladder no more, but a blasted bloody film now -- a nothing for the Harpies and the souls of dead sailors to peck and claw and feed upon, only to be lapped up and swallowed by the infinite waters of the dread emperor himself, forgotten to any man, to any time, forgotten to any god or devil, forgotten even to the sea... for any stuff or part of Winslow, even any scantling of your soul, is Winslow no more, but is now itself the sea. OLD is shaking like a lunatic. Veins popping in every direction. Exhausted... eyes drilling into YOUNG. YOUNG sweats. What can he do? What can he say? Has he bee cursed? Doomed?  62.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Alright. Have it your way. I like yer cooking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cataclysmic storm continues. Flash. The wind. Flash. The rain. Flash. The waves. Flash. The foghorn. Flash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PUSHES IN ON: YOUNG watching the light through the lens deck. Hypnotized.

dialogues.speaker: SMILING. SHAKING. INSANE
dialogues.text: WHISPERING ABOVE. Or is it just the spinning lens? The sound is familiar and alien. Male and female. Celesti He pulls out THE DINNER KNIFE and holds it to the light.. He smiles like a Jack-o'-lantern. Hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG unlaces his boots and puts them in his pockets, hee up. He creeps toward the TOWER like a stocking-footed burglar.  63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG slinks up the stairs. INT. MACHINE ROOM —- MOMENTS LATER YOUNG is trying to pick the LOCK of the LANTERN ROOM with DINNER KNIFE. HE is twisting and turning the KNIFE roughly in the lock. Twisting... Jiggling... SUDDENLY, the knife blade breaks in two...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Son-of-a-bitch. He looks at the KNIFE. It’s now very thin. Needle-like. A idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG tiptoes to Old’s DESK with THE THIN, BROKEN DINNER KNIFE... He can hear OLD snoring (0.S.) upstairs. He brings it to THE LOCK... He jiggles the knife... the top jiggles too... It’s unlocked already! He quietly opens the desk... THE LOG BOOK is gone. Son-of-a-bitch. OLD keeps snoring (0.S.).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG watches OLD sleep. THE LOGBOOK and spectacles rise fall on his belly. His loud SNORE follows. THE BRASS KEYS hang on their chain, his watch tucked under his pillow.  64. WATER DRIPS from the ceiling, plinking into a pail. YOUNG creeps forward toward OLD, trying not to make any noise. The sounds of THE STORM outside help to disguise s of his movements. And the plink... plink... plink... OLD keeps snoring... Every step is silent... Plink... plink... plink... He reaches his hand out, unfurling like a lure in slow- motion, fishing for... the BRASS KEYS... YOUNG sees OLD’S sweaty THROAT... Pause. YOUNG slowly brings the KNIFE out... Another step forward... The floorboards betray YOUNG with a loud GROAN. YOUNG stops. Caught! He quickly throws his knife hand beh his back. OLD opens one eye.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Queer way to wear yer shoes.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Didn’t wanna wake you, is all. Pause. Long night. Pause. And such.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Mm-hm. The sun is over the yardarm. Best find me some winks afore the day draws farther on. OLD FARTS. Pause. YOUNG stands still.  65.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get to yer duties or I'll give you a real keelhauling. Pause. YOUNG stands still, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: You ain’t even human no more. Workin’ apart from folks so long. What’d you lose? Pause.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yer only tol’rable when yer dunk.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Get to work, says I! YOUNG STANDS STILL, DEFIANTLY. CAMERA REVEALS: THE KNIFE STILL HIDDEN IN YOUNG’S HAND.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To work! Pause. OLD FARTS. YOUNG SMILES AGAIN, A WEIRD, FALSE SMILE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG wears his OILSKINS, pushing the wheelbarrow through tempest. It’s almost impossible. Is he drunk or hung-over HE MUTTERS TO HIMSELF. He has a BOTTLE in the barrow, floating in rain water. Th it. No coal. YOUNG keeps his eye on the bottle. Watching Caring for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fog machine whirls, pumps and... BELLOWS! YOUNG shovels a heap of coal into the furnace. Shirt off. OILSKIN HAT on.  66. He takes a swig from the bottle. THE FIRE ROARS. ANOTHER BIG, LONG SWIG.

dialogues.speaker: THE GALE IS MERCILESS AS EVER.
dialogues.text: YOUNG is pulling up THE ROPE OF A LOBSTER POT... IMAGE: THE MERMAID’S BREAST. IMAGE: HER MOUTH. YOUNG pulling the rope... IMAGE: THE LIGHTHOUSE, at a 45 degree angle, LOOKING LIKE PENIS. YOUNG pulling the rope... IMAGE: THE MERMAID’S SLIMY VAGINA. IMAGE: YOUNG’S HANDS TIGHTLY GRIP A CANT HOOK.

dialogues.speaker: IMAGE
dialogues.text: IMAGE: THE MERMAID’S FACE, UPSIDE DOWN. SCREAMING, MOANIN EYES ROLLED INTO THE BACK OF HER HEAD. YOUNG pulling... IMAGE: CLOSE ON: THE BACK OF A MAN’S HEAD. WOOL MACKINAW COLLAR.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG IS MASTURBATING IN THE DARK. FURIOUS. ANGRY. CONFUS
dialogues.text: Shirt off. Oilskin hat on. Shivering. Rain pisses down through the holes in the roof. He is holding the MERMAID CARVING. Staring at it. It’s no working. He throws his head back, thinking of someone, something. does it with a fury... lust...  67. It’s taking too long to get anywhere. Back to the MERMAID CARVING... Beat. Beat. Beat. Beat. Beat. His hand is getting tired. Beat. Beat. Beat. Beat. Beat. He can feel something coming, it’s rising within him, he his other hand on the rickety wall... it’s coming... soon He’s lost it. IMAGE: WIDE: YOUNG is straddling the MERMAID (the real on not the carving), his pants half down, FUCKING HER WHILE SEA LAPS OVER THEM.

dialogues.speaker: IMAGE
dialogues.text: IMAGE: THE MERMAID’S HANDS GRAB YOUNG'S THROAT, DRAGGING INTO THE SEA AND SLIME. IMAGE: A MAN’S FACE (not Young’s), SURROUNDED BY A MACKIN COLLAR, GURGLES, SCREAMING, SUBMERGED IN WATER. BACK TO THE SHED: YOUNG howls, an animal in an iron trap! HE THROWS THE MERMAID CARVING...

dialogues.speaker: IT BREAKS IN TWO
dialogues.text: Desire quickly turns to shame. The foghorn calls. The wind howls. Rain pours into the sh YOUNG looks at the broken MERMAID and curls into a ball o the wet ground with his pants around his hips... He seems like he is about to cry... But he laughs. He laughs as if a great weight has been lifted.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I fixed you. You bastard. You can’t git to me. I’1l get yer gullet! He crawls to the broken carving and starts wildly stabbin with the DINNER KNIFE! IMAGE: YOUNG is pulling the rope down by the rocks... HE PULLS UP THE LOBSTER POT...  68. BACK IN THE SHED: YOUNG, SEIZED WITH FRIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: THUNDER CLAPS.
dialogues.text: YOUNG AND OLD are singing, dancing, do-si-do-ing, swingin each other with linked elbows around the room in circles.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (singing) She swung her hips, she winked her eyes, that sassy little whore, So I took her in, I gave her gin, and danced her on the floor!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG AND OLD
dialogues.text: (singing) Doodle let me go, me girls, doodle let me go, Hurrah, me yaller girls, doodle let me go!

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (singing) Oh ‘round and ‘round the sofa, boys, wasn't it a show She grabbed hold of my bobstay and she wouldn't let it go! They laugh, and break away from each other... OLD begins diddling “Ten Penny Bit” and dancing a jig. (Diddling is a kind of maritime scat-singing that mimics fiddle) YOUNG claps while OLD dances.
