His dancing is pretty impressive, especially with his bad leg. How’s it possibl YOUNG joins the diddling and jigging... OLD begins clapping, too. He claps a little faster, YOUNG matches his tempo.  69. IT’S COMPETITIVE. FIERCE. MEAN. They diddle, jig, and clap faster and faster and faster a faster...

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dance! Dance, Winslow! Dance!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: (singing, very, very, very fast) Come all you boys who wish to hear How we got up to the woods last year, Oh, into the sleigh we jacked our boots Our teamster pointed to the big blue spruce Timmy-ran-tin-ah Falla-doo-a-dah Rant-and-roar and drunk-on-the-way! Timmy-ran-tin-ah Falla-doo-a-dah-- LIGHTNING FLASHES THROUGH THE WINDOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG AND OLD are slow dancing. Arms around each others’ shoulders. Tired. YOUNG looks at him with anger and suspicion. OLD sings a ballad. His voice isn’t exactly pretty, or al on key, but the ballad is beautiful, with a haunting melo and his performance is moving. He’s deep into it, experiencing every moment.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (singing) Oh, where have all the evenings gone? Oh, where is the ale and whisky I’ve tasted? Gone the same way as the pay I done wasted, On a Monday morning. If but the birds were gin, If but the sun was a hearty reveler, If I might give someone else me liver, On a Monday morning. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My lover she lies asleep, My lover is warm, and her heart is mellow, I would give the whole world just to share her pillow, THE SONG has changed YOUNG’S mood, he has softened... Timidly and quietly, he joins the last line...

dialogues.speaker: OLD AND YOUNG
dialogues.text: (half-singing) On a Monday morning. Thunder rumbles... They lean into each other... It is very tense... It seems like they might kiss... No, that’s madness. Pause. YOUNG pushes OLD away. He puts up his fists like an old-t boxer. OLD does, too. They take turns hitting each other, play fighting. OLD ke hitting YOUNG, as YOUNG is more drunk.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: You bastard. THE PLAY-FIGHTING ESCALATES... THE PUNCHES GROW HARDER... THEN... YOUNG grabs OLD and hurls him against the moldy cabinet! cackles. THEY send the whole cabinet of cups and dishes clattering down. OLD throws plates at YOUNG, almost hitting him... dinnerw smashing on the walls. They start throwing the scraps of fish bones and potato s from their plates at each other... laughing. They're hysterically drunk. Demented. YOUNG throws the soapbox... It breaks apart against the  71. range! They get closer to each other, running out of things to throw. Howling laughing...

dialogues.speaker: -PARLOR. LATER
dialogues.text: OLD pulls out another bottle and slams it down in front o YOUNG.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Drink.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Aye, aye, sir.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: In one draft.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: You do it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: GODDAMN YER CALUMNY! The law says ye do as I command! Any word but “aye” be mutiny! Pause. YOUNG pulls the cork off. He drinks, and drinks, liquor pouring down the sides of his stubbly face.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Atta boy!!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Aye, aye, AYE, AYE! AYE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOTH of them pour booze all over their faces. THUNDER CLAPS. LIGHTING FLASHES THROUGH THE WINDOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG is so drunk, it’s hard to believe. He is soaked in liquor. OLD has his head on YOUNG'S shoulder. He falls in and out consciousness.  Pause. Pause. 72.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Aye?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: It’s Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: No, I... I’m Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: I'm Thomas. You’re Ephraim.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I lied.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Well, I‘1ll be scuppered.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I’m Thomas. Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Tommy ? (laughs) Tommy Winslow.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Tom Howard.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: What’s Winslow?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Nothing?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: It ain’t my fault... I...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I trust you? OLD sits up. Thunder rumbles.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Don’t be spilling any of yer beans to me.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: No... It wasn’t that way, is all...

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: I ain’t interested.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: So I can trust you?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Never did like being confided to.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I know what you’re fixin’ to do. Git me all liquored up--

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Yer guilty conscience is ever as tiresome-borin’ as any a guilty conscience.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: It was a drive, see...

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Worse.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: A log drive and... he’s raggin’ on me. No -- I see what yer doing...

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Look, I mean, look, Tom... don’t be working to twist words out of my head.  74.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: I ain't.

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: look... I can’t, I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Shut up yer own rag box.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I can trust you.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I trust you, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Y’trust me?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: No. I don’t trust you at all. They laugh. They drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CLOCK ticks monotonously. Somehow, the sounds of the storm have diminished. The plinking slowly disappears, to CLOSE ON: YOUNG looking feral-eyed. Utterly still.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: And I had ‘im handy and helpless. Alone. Too far downstream. And I wanted to do ‘im in. I admit I did. Seein’ the back of his head. One swipe of the cant hook’d be all. It was... I didn’t... but I didn’t... I did not. The day was long as hell on that drive. I was lead-tired. I admit it. But I saw him slippin’, not me. And we saw the jam comin’. And I stood and he slipped. He shouted up. And I just stood. “Tom, you dog!” And I stood, is all. Just stood and watched ‘im git swallowed down by them logs. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All I thought when he was done is, “I could use me a smoke.” That’s it. So, I packed up his kit and fixins, as if they was mine. And, well, Ephraim Winslow has a spiffy clean slate. Thomas Howard, he don’t. No prospects. How else am I gonna find respectable work? Pause. YOUNG turns. OLD is gone... Did he even hear this?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tom? Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tom?!

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (far away, whispered, echoing) Why’d y’spill yer beans, Tommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD’S voice echoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chains clink, echoing too...

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (whispered) Why’d y’spill yer beans? YOUNG ascends the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DOOR to the CATWALK FLIES open... Rain blows wildly into the machine room. YOUNG goes through the door...  76.

dialogues.speaker: THE WIND AND RAIN ARE VICIOUS ON THE WALKWAY ATOP THE TOW
dialogues.text: They push and slap YOUNG as he carefully makes his way to A BODY. It’s face down. Is it the OLD man? NO. But it’s familiar - the MACKINAW COAT... THE HIGH LEATHER BOOTS WITH THICK HOBNAILED SOLES... For some reason, known least to YOUNG, he reaches out for familiar man and turns the wet body over: IT'S YOUNG! HIS DOPPELGANGER. PALE. DEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG tries to get away. But he can't. The OLD man is too strong. And something starts to happen. Something horribl THE OLD MAN SLOWLY OPENS HIS EYES. YOUNG's expression tells it all: fascination moves quickl through confusion and deep, unknown terror as ...

dialogues.speaker: A LIGHT BRIGHTER THAN ANYTHING BATHES YOUNG'S FACE
dialogues.text: OLD'S EYES SHINE LIKE THE LIGHTHOUSE BEACON INTO YOUNG’S FACE.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BOATHOUSE
dialogues.text: YOUNG tries with utter desperation to launch the DORY out sea. He throws on a CORK LIFE VEST. HUGE WAVES CRASH AGAINST HIM.  77. It is a bitter struggle as he drags the DORY along the runners... YOUNG throws the OARS in the boat... Suddenly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD chases YOUNG across the island, wielding the axe... YOUNG runs into the QUARTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD bursts in and swings the AXE at YOUNG, missing... OLD buries THE AXE deep in the kitchen table. He falls wi exhaustion. They are both soaking wet.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: You crazy son-of-a-bitch! You smashed up the life boat!

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Yer abandoning yer post! YOUNG storms into the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WATER is leaking from the ceiling, heavily. It flows down of the walls.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: What’re you gonna do? Send for the lighthouse establishment?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Certain, says I! I’1l report ye, I‘ll bring the inspector up--  78.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I’ll report you. I know what you done...

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Who’s reportin’ who? Ephraim Winslow? Or Thomas Howard? I know what you done--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: (suddenly) You killed yer second. YOUNG SMILES.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: For once, OLD is speechless. In horror. YOUNG is happy as can be. Crazed. Manic.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I found him. Yer one-eyed junior man. In the lobster pot. He went mad? You made him mad with that charm! That scrimshaw trinket, it’s a sea spell to keep him from yer secret... But I broke it, see. I’m free. YOUNG rummages awkwardly through his pockets and finds th broken pieces of the IVORY MERMAID. He throws it to OLD’S feet! Young smiles in triumph and does a celebratory jig!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Free from yer designs! OLD makes no expression. YOUNG stops jigging.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I got it all figgerd out, ‘cept what’s the secret mischief yer keepin’...  79. He points to THE LANTERN ROOM. .-. up there!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I figgerd you, old timer. This whole time, I’ve been watchin’ you and I’ve got you figgerd. OLD looks at YOUNG with pity.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Jesus, Mary and Joseph, Tommy. Last night you made a confession ‘twould make a saint swear. I don’t have nothin’ to confess, but you, Tommy, a-spillin’ yer beans... now look what it’s done to ye. It’s made ye mad. I knew ye was mad when y’smashed up the life boat just now, a-chasing me with an axe, tryin’ to kill ‘Ol Tom. Don't y’trust me, Tommy?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Better hand me the dinner knife you pocketed. Y’aint safe with it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Them’s government property. YOUNG does so, looking like a guilty child.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s a good lad. OLD, stepping on it, breaks it in two and throws it in th stove.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Deducted from yer pay.  80.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Look at yer shiverin’. Yer so mad, y'know not up from down. How long have we been on this rock? Five week? Two days? Where are we? Help me to recollect, who are you again, Tommy ?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: I’m probably a fig’ment of your ‘magination. This rock is a fig’ment of yer ‘magination, too. Yer probably wand’rin’ through a grove of tag alders, up in north Canady, like a frostbitten maniac a- talkin’ to yerself, knee-deep in the snow, the blizzard overtakin’ ye. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I could use a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: We're outta drink. They smile at each other like old friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HONEY DRIBBLES into a BRASS KEROSENE CANISTER. YOUNG still wears the cork vest as he drips the HONEY, smoking his cigarette. OLD watches with intense curiosity. YOUNG TAKES OUT A TIN OF TURPENTINE. He pours it into the CANISTER, too. He begins to stir it with a scrap of rebar

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Thieves’ oil. YOUNG smells it. He likes it. He pours OLD a cup.  81. OLD drinks.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Oooooh, monkey pump! They both drink... fighting over it like giddy children.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FOG SIGNAL HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: THE BAROMETER. The needle is falling. It falls “storm” to a blank space below. Off the chart, so to spea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will it survive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG and OLD laugh and laugh and laugh, holding cups of thieves’ oil. YOUNG still wears the life vest. WATER DRIP

dialogues.speaker: AND POURS FROM THE CEILING
dialogues.text: THE AXE in the table top between them. They keep laughing in a frighteningly hysterical manner.. Laughing... Laughing... Laughing... Laughing... Laughing... SUDDENLY, THE FORCE OF A WAVE CRASHES THROUGH A WINDOW... WATER FLOODS INTO THE ROOM WITH RAPID SPEED. But YOUNG & don’t notice. They keep laughing... Laughing...  82. Laughing... Laughing... Laughing... Laughing... HOLD. BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE KITCHEN is an absolute catastrophe. However terrible looked the night before, it is even worse now. Mess is everywhere and every surface is soaking wet. Water drips way that suggests the storm is over. The quarters utterly destroyed, and by the looks of it, not just by the storm. THE AXE still stays buried in the table. YOUNG is sitting in the SINK, drinking TURPENTINE straigh from the tin. He’s in his undershirt and trousers, but st wearing the life vest.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: This place is a sty.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mornin’ to you, too.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I wish I could go fer a walk.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Be my guest. You’ll get drowned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CLOCK ticks monotonously. The room is half flooded. YOUNG stands in ankle deep wate pissing, missing the chamber pot, following it around as floats across the room. As he does this, he is taking off life vest... Suddenly, he begin to retch... he throws up. He falls to his knees... splash... and sees... OLD’S LOGBOOK... it floats by... OPEN.  83. YOUNG fumbles around to snatch it up, to bring it to the window light. He begins to leaf through the pages... There are beautiful mementos of Old’s past, newspaper clippings, tintypes... YOUNG finds locks of Old’s children’s hair... he touches gently... Then... HE FINDS THE LOG ENTRIES... (CAMERA doesn’t see the entri YOUNG almost slams it shut. But he doesn’t. He keeps reading... YOUNG'S face drops. The CLOCK’S ticking seems to grow lou every second. YOUNG looks like a ghost. HE SMASHES THE CLOCK WITH HIS FIST. No more ticking. Glass and blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLD sits in a heap of trash. He’s wearing only his sweaty baggy, mostly unbuttoned union suit, his vest with his wa chain, and his cap. He smokes his PIPE... It goes out.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Damn. He tries to find a match in the chaos.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to himself) Fiery pit! Ain’t there no justice left in this world? He roots through the rubbish, throwing it around... Suddenly, the sound of a MATCH striking (0.S.)! OLD turns around, startled.  84. YOUNG is right behind OLD... with a LIT MATCH... utterly still. Eerily still. He calmly lights OLD’S PIPE. OLD feels a bit uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thankee. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with yer hand? YOUNG looks at the match hand in confusion.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: T’other one. YOUNG looks: his left hand leaves blood marks on the tabl He slithers his cut hand away.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ye hear o’ tetanus?

dialogues.speaker: OLD YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tet-a-nus? (quietly, rigid) Yep.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: It started as a sliver of a cut is all... YOUNG is motionless. Boiling.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I said I heard of it.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: ... from the forestaysail when we shoved off...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Can’t you never shut up.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: «+. but come a fortnight...  85.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: The bosun was a-shakin’...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Shut up, I says.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: ... his chops was locked tighter than an anchor bend-- YOUNG explodes:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: SHUT IT! I told you I can’t hear no more! Hold yer jaw!

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: What were it yer accused me of? Y’already told me y’had me figgerd--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I’m tired out of listening to your damned-fool yarns and your Cap’n Ahab horseshit -- you sound like a goddamned parody. Givin’ and nagging orders like a spinster schoolmarm... and... and...

dialogues.speaker: OLD YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to himself) all-the-while turning this ‘Nother conniption fit. station to the Devil’s own (to Young) rum hole. Yer makin’ a fool of yerelf.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, it’s all horseshit, yer leg, and yer sea life, all of it. And I’m tired of it. If I hear one more word of horseshit coming from your foul, rotten tooth, smelly old mouth--

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Ye--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Shut up yer gum, Goddamn it -- I ain’t finished. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sick of lookin’ at you, I’m sick of lookin’ at week-old food in yer beard starin’ me in the face like it ‘spects me of somethin’. You think yer so damned high and mighty cause yer a goddamned lighthouse keeper? Well, you ain’t a captain of no ship and you never was, you ain’t no general, no copper, you ain’t the president, and you ain’t my father -- and I’m sick of you actin’ like you is! I’m sick of yer orders! I’m sick of your laughing, your snoring, and your goddamned farts. Your damned goddamned farts. Goddamn yer farts! You smell like piss, you smell like jism, like rotten dick, like curdled foreskin, like hot onions fucked a farmyard shit-house. And I'm sick of yer smell. I’m sick of it! I’m sick of it, you goddamned drunk. You goddamned, no-account, drunken, son-of-a-bitch-bastard- liar! That’s what you are, you're a goddamned drunken horse-shitting -- short -- shit liar. A liar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pause.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Y’have a way with words, Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Damn you.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Yer relieved of yer duties.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: No need to tell me, old timer. YOUNG reveals the LOG book. He reads aloud:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Assistant slept late. Work below standard. Turns the page.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Attitude Hostile  87. Turns several pages.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Assistant missing. Given to habitual ‘self-abuse’ in the supply shed. A few more pages.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Drunk on duty. Turns a page.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Incoherent speech. Another page.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Attempted to abandon his post. Assault. Theft. Another page.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I do not feel safe with him. Recommend severance without pay.

dialogues.speaker: SEVERANCE WITHOUT PAY
dialogues.text: YOUNG throws THE LOGBOOK at him.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yer trying to ruin me?! I’m a hard worker! I am! I work as hard as any man!

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Ye lie, Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop it. Y’lie to yerself, but y’ain’t have the sauce to see it. YOUNG changes his tune:  88.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Work as hard as a man and two horses, you said so yerself, I work like I’m a damn foreigner. YOUNG works at getting into the BREEZEWAY toward the TOWE OLD stands in his way. YOUNG begs, desperately:

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please, please, let me into the light, old man, and I’11 show you what I can do for -- I can -- I can do better -- I can. I’ve learned so much from you. Another chance. Let me show you. Forgive and forgit, I says -- just let me into that lantern, is all, don’t make me beg-- I will -- I’1l beg if that’s what you want, PLEASE-- OLD keeps his ground.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Stand down.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: SELFISH BASTARD! Keepin’ it all to yerself. Left yer old lady, yer children for what? For what?! OLD smiles. Creepily.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Look at ye, handsome lad, with eyes bright as a lady. Come to this rock playin’ the tough, ye make me laugh with yer false grum. Ye pretended to some mystery in yer quietudes, but there ain’t no mystery, yer an open book. A picture, says I. A painted actress screaming in the footlights, a bitch what wants to be coveted for nothin’ but being born, cryin’ bout the silver spoon what should've been yers. Now look at ye cryin’.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Boo! Boo! What’re y’to do? Look at ye. Look at ye. Will y’kill me? Will ye? Will y’kill me like y’done that gull?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: I didn’t--

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Damn you!

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: ‘TWAS YE WHAT DAMNED US, DOG! ‘TWAS YE! Will y’do what y’wish y’done to ol’ Winslow?

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Would ye best me then? If y’break, I win. If I break ye, I still win.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: I always win because yer less a man than I -- and them’s the rules of nature. Them’s truth. I am truth. I make the truth as I see fit. Me. And the truth is that yer a nothin’, Tommy-Tom-Tom. A nothing but a dog what thinks he’s the master when he pulls on his master’s leash. Well if you pull on my leash, I'll choke ye, Thomas Howard, I‘ll strangle ye, fer Winslow were right: You’re A DOG,

dialogues.speaker: OLD AND YOUNG ATTACK EACH OTHER AT THE SAME TIME
dialogues.text: EACH OTHERS’ THROATS! EYES BULGE.  90. OLD GRINS WILDLY... YOUNG GRINS BACK... YOUNG STARTS KICKING OLD IN HIS BAD LEG... OLD CRUMBLES TO THE GROUND -- he tries to get up... YOUNG KICKS OLD IN THE SPINE... OLD’S FOREHEAD SMACKS AGAINST THE FLOOR. HARD. It bleeds.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GETS ON TOP OF OLD AND TURNS HIM AROUND. OLD GRABS
dialogues.text: YOUNG’S SHOULDERS.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Shut up! Shut up! Shut up! THEY ARE VIOLENTLY WRESTLING... ANIMALISTIC GRUNTING... BREATHING... SWEATING... LEGS ENTWINED... VEINY THROATS.. VEINY BICEPS... MOVING BACK AND FORTH, BACK AND FORTH... WRESTLING... BREATHING... GRUNTING... SWEATING... SUDDENLY, YOUNG LOOKS DOWN... IT’S NO LONGER OLD... IT’S EPHRAIM WINSLOW in his mackinaw coat... YOUNG IS IN TERROR... WINSLOW SPITS IN YOUNG'S FACE...

dialogues.speaker: OLD...
dialogues.text: ONLY IT’S NOT: HE IS NAKED, HIS BEARD IS LONGER, COVERED SEAWEED... AND HE HAS ENORMOUS SQUID TENTACLES FOR LEGS.. YOUNG PUNCHES OLD, AND SEA WATER FLOWS FROM HIS MOUTH...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG PUNCHES OLD AGAIN, BRUTALLY
dialogues.text: A TENTACLE WRAPS AROUND YOUNG’S THROAT, SQUEEZING...

dialogues.speaker: YER KILLING ME
dialogues.text: Suddenly... YOUNG looks down. It’s OLD. Bloody. Whimpering. 91. No mer-person, no Winslow, just an old, weeping man that YOUNG has beat to a pulp. YOUNG stands, breathing heavily. He pulls up his suspende He wipes the sweat from his brow. OLD lies motionless, ju breathing and letting out his almost inaudible whimper. YOUNG leans on the table. Very, very long pause. Pause. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Bark. Bark boy, bark, laddy. Bark!

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: (very, very weak) Woof.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Ain’t you never been to sea bark I says, bark!

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Arf.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Bark, laddy! before,  92.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Ruff! Ruff!!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Now, there’s a good boy. There’s a good dog. Long pause. Now roll over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storm has indeed ended. Clapboards and shingles have torn from the quarters. The supply shed is nowhere to be seen. YOUNG walks OLD on a leash, well, a rope around his neck. crawls on all fours.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Good boy. YOUNG walks OLD to the GRAVE-SIZED HOLE they dug out.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Git in there, you old dog. Where you belong. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You do as I say, dog! OLD slinks into the wet, muddy grave. He settles down, se submerged in a foot or so of water and sludge.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s my good lad. YOUNG picks up a shovel... He begins to bury OLD.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: No! YOUNG puts more dirt and mud on him...

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Y’'wish to see what’s in that lantern? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So did me last assistant. YOUNG shovels mud onto OLD’S face...

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Shut up, dog. Polish yer brasswork. He keeps shoveling... OLD laughs, blood pouring out of his mouth. Dying.

dialogues.speaker: OLD
dialogues.text: Y’said yer a God fearin’ man, Tommy? (laughs) Them’s truth, Tommy ! More mud on him...

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: O what Protean forms swim up from men’s minds and melt in hot Promethean plunder scorching eyes with divine shames and horrors More mud on him...

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: and cast them down to Davy Jones. And others, still blind, yet in it see all divine graces and to Fiddler’s Green sent, where no man is suffered to want and toil, but is Dirt on his face... ancient Mud... mutable More mud on his face... and unchanging as the she who girdles ‘round the globe. More mud... Them’s truth. And you’ll be punished. OLD becomes stifled from the dirt and mud.  94. Long pause. Is he dead? Suddenly, YOUNG panics... He jumps into the grave and starts digging out OLD with h hands... Digging and digging and sloshing... He lifts OLD up. He holds him. Pause. YOUNG catches his breath. YOUNG takes the BRASS KEYS from OLD’S vest... He let’s OLD fall into the mud, still as a stone. YOUNG walks away. YOUNG doesn’t see it, but several GULLS fly into frame be him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG slowly approaches the long staircase. He looks up... He puts his hands on the railing... He is ready to go into the lantern room at last. But something stops him... No, he can’t go on. He pats his breast pocket... no smokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG walks through the galley. He goes to the table... THERE IT IS: HIS POUCH OF TOBACCO. He begins to roll a cigarette... He looks down: Staring at him is A HOLE IN THE MIDDLE OF THE TABLE -- BU THE AXE IS GONE...  95.

dialogues.speaker: OLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: THE LIGHT B’LONGS TO ME! OLD, covered in mud, barely alive, swings THE AXE, cuttin into YOUNG’S shoulder. Blood gushes from the wound. YOUNG picks up the IRON KETTLE and swings around, bashing in THE FACE. OLD falls hard to the ground, groaning... YOUNG PICKS UP THE AXE... HE LIFTS IT HIGH... OLD tries to guard himself with his hands... YOUNG DRIVES THE AXE INTO OLD’S HEAD WITH A BLOOD CURDLIN CRUNCH! (OLD’S head is 0.S. but it is clear that this is happened). BLOOD SPLATTERS ACROSS THE ROOM. His old limbs seize for moment and drop back to the floor. Pause. YOUNG limps, covered in blood, back to the table. He rolls the cigarette, his hands shaking. He smokes it. He pours some turpentine into a nearby cup. He looks at OLD, the axe handle sticking up from his head YOUNG lifts the cup. Hand shaking. He toasts.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG
dialogues.text: Should pale death with treble dread make the ocean caves our bed, God who hear'st the surges roll, deign to save the suppliant soul. He drinks. Hold. MUSIC CUE: The eerie “light” music. Continues to the end the film.  96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawling, trembling, and bleeding, YOUNG slowly works his to the tower...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG continues, slowly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG ascends the ladder, slowly, and using THE KEY, HE O THE HATCH that leads into the LANTERN ROOM... The dazzling LIGHT swirling... YOUNG is hypnotized...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG looks ahead... There it is: THE FRESNEL LENS. It is a massive, six-foot- jewel of indescribable beauty with eight shimmering brass legs. It seems to sing... He walks toward it... As if by magic, the LENS’ rotation begins to decelerate.. The LENS stops turning... He marvels at it. Slowly, the doors of the lens open like wings, facing him The light grows brighter... Pause. He takes it in. Pause. A tear falls from his eye. He smiles. Slowly, he puts his hand into the light...  97. A deep, bassy, fire-crackling sound is heard as he touche the flames... THE LIGHT grows brighter... His hand is burning, but he keeps reaching... The crackling sound growing louder and more otherworldly. YOUNG starts to shake with insanity... His face distorts... THE LIGHT GROWS BRIGHTER... YOUNG SCREAMS... BRIGHTER... INCONCEIVABLY BRIGHT... YOUNG starts trembling, crying, he’s terrified of what he seen... He cannot fathom it... He foams at the mouth.... He teeters... He’s loosing his balance... he’s falling... He falls backward out of frame... OUT OF THE LANTERN ROOM... SLAM. INTO THE MACHINE ROOM... BANG. AND DOWN THE STAIRS... .--All the way down the long winding staircase, tumbling, tumbling, grunting, twisting, bones breaking, and clangin down four stories of stairs until YOUNG lands with a dull bloody... THUD. Is he breathing? FADE TO WHITE.  98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG lies naked, splayed out on the rocks, bones broken. He is blind. His eyes are bloody, burnt-out sockets. He c move. Seaweed is wrapped around him. A seabird pecks at his abdomen... Peck. Peck. Peck. It is THE ONE-EYED GULL... It pulls at YOUNG’S liver... YOUNG groans... Dozens and dozens of BIRDS fly to YOUNG, overwhelming him Eating him. CAMERA pulls back to reveal him alone, on PILOT ROCK. (CA doesn’t pull back far enough to see the lighthouse or outbuildings.) Only YOUNG and a swarm of seabirds eating him. HOLD. THE END.
